Selected bond lengths [Å] and angles [°]: Cu1-O1 1.931(3), Cu1-O4 1.912(3), Cu1-O10 1.976(3), Cu1-O12 v  2.336(3), Cu1-N1 1.938(4), Na1-O1 2.698(4), Na1-O11 2.243(4), Na1-O11 i  2.842(4), Na1-O12 i  2.374(4), Na1-O13 v  2.348(4), Na1-O20 2.393(4), N1-N2 1.284(5). O4-Cu1-O1 174.28(14), N1-Cu1-O10 163.34(15), N1-Cu1-O12 113.92(15), O11-Na1-O20 97.02(14), O11-Na1-O1 73.23(12), O11 i  -Na1-O13 v  119.53(13), O20-Na1-O1 159.92(14). Symmetry operation to generate equivalent atoms: (i) 1-x, -y,1-z; (ii) -x, -y, 1-z; (iii) 2-x, -y, 1-z; (iv) -1+x,y,z; (v) 1+x, y, z.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new aqua-soluble Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>-Na coordination polymer, {[Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>-L)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>, was easily generated by self-assembly from copper(II) nitrate, sodium hydroxide and 2-hydroxy-5-nitro-3-(2-(2,4,6-trioxotetrahydropyrimidin-5(2H)-ylidene)hydrazinyl)benzene sulfonic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L) a new hydrosoluble arylhydrazone of barbituric acid. The complex was characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental and single‐crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, which disclosed 1D metal-organic chains driven by the intricate nona-chelation of the fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> derivative to five metal cations (three Na<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> and two Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>). These chains have intercalated crystallization water molecules enabling the expansion of the structure to 3D by means of extensive hydrogen bond interactions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new aqua-soluble CuII-Na coordination polymer, {[Cu(H2O)Na(H2O)(η 9-L)]⋅2H2O}n, was easily generated by self-assembly from copper(II) nitrate, sodium hydroxide and 2-hydroxy-5-nitro-3-(2-(2,4,6-trioxotetrahydropyrimidin-5(2H)-ylidene)hydrazinyl)benzene sulfonic acid (H3L) a new hydrosoluble arylhydrazone of barbituric acid. The complex was characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, which disclosed 1D metal-organic chains driven by the intricate nona-chelation of the fully deprotonated L3- derivative to five metal cations (three NaI and two CuII). These chains have intercalated crystallization water molecules enabling the expansion of the structure to 3D by means of extensive hydrogen bond interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">A new aqua-soluble Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>-Na 1D coordination polymer with intercalated crystallization water molecules has been synthesized by using arylhydrazone of barbituric acid as a nonadentate versatile ligand.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A new aqua-soluble CuII-Na 1D coordination polymer with intercalated crystallization water molecules has been synthesized by using arylhydrazone of barbituric acid as a nonadentate versatile ligand.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">► A new type of aqua-soluble copper(II)-sodium heterometallic coordination polymer has been prepared and fully characterized. ► Previously unknown arylhydrazone of barbituric acid was used for the ﬁrst time as a nonadentate versatile ligand. ► Intercalated water clusters support the overall 3D supramolecular arrangement.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► A new type of aqua-soluble copper(II)-sodium heterometallic coordination polymer has been prepared and fully characterized. ► Previously unknown arylhydrazone of barbituric acid was used for the ﬁrst time as a nonadentate versatile ligand. ► Intercalated water clusters support the overall 3D supramolecular arrangement.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Coordination chemistry of arylhydrazones of active methylene compounds (AHAMC) has been extensively developed due to the comparably easy procedure of their preparation from cheap and available starting materials combined with the high potential of such compounds to sequester metal ions with formation of metal complexes. For example, arylhydrazones of β-diketones contain a flexible O,N,O donor site which can chelate a number of metal ions, thus leading to Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
, Na<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
, K<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>
, Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
, Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
 complexes of different nuclearities and topologies. Moreover, the first example of an heterometallic Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>-K AHAMC complex has been recently reported by some of us . The preparative procedures for these complexes are usually straightforward and can give high yields of the final products. Also it was demonstrated, that by modification of the methylene active moiety or by introduction of different substituents to the aromatic part of AHAMCs one can significantly change the nuclearity and overall topology of the formed complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Coordination chemistry of arylhydrazones of active methylene compounds (AHAMC) has been extensively developed due to the comparably easy procedure of their preparation from cheap and available starting materials combined with the high potential of such compounds to sequester metal ions with formation of metal complexes. For example, arylhydrazones of β-diketones contain a flexible O,N,O donor site which can chelate a number of metal ions, thus leading to CuII , ZnII , NiII , NaI , KI , PbII , CdII , CoII  complexes of different nuclearities and topologies. Moreover, the first example of an heterometallic CuII-K AHAMC complex has been recently reported by some of us . The preparative procedures for these complexes are usually straightforward and can give high yields of the final products. Also it was demonstrated, that by modification of the methylene active moiety or by introduction of different substituents to the aromatic part of AHAMCs one can significantly change the nuclearity and overall topology of the formed complexes .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Aquasolubility of the AHMACs and their complexes would be particularly important for green catalytic applications, pharmaceutical and other activities where water is an essential solvent or/and a reactant . Introduction of a hydrophilic polar (e.g., sulfo- or nitro-) group into the ligand is one of the common ways to increase the water solubility of its complexes; moreover, the introduced moieties can behave as additional coordinating sites thus supporting an extension of coordination arrays in the solid state  and/or inducing the formation of heterometallic complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Aquasolubility of the AHMACs and their complexes would be particularly important for green catalytic applications, pharmaceutical and other activities where water is an essential solvent or/and a reactant . Introduction of a hydrophilic polar (e.g., sulfo- or nitro-) group into the ligand is one of the common ways to increase the water solubility of its complexes; moreover, the introduced moieties can behave as additional coordinating sites thus supporting an extension of coordination arrays in the solid state  and/or inducing the formation of heterometallic complexes .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The derivatives of barbituric acid are widely used in therapy for many diseases varying from simple sedation to cancer treatment , probably due to the susceptibility of the acidic hydrogen to rapid metabolic attack and subsequent degradation of the compounds within the body . The biological activities of arylhydrazones of barbituric acid (AHBA) also attracted some attention , but have not been further investigated. Moreover, the coordination chemistry of AHBA ligands is almost unexplored , and deserves more attention in particular towards the preparation of water-soluble polymeric complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The derivatives of barbituric acid are widely used in therapy for many diseases varying from simple sedation to cancer treatment , probably due to the susceptibility of the acidic hydrogen to rapid metabolic attack and subsequent degradation of the compounds within the body . The biological activities of arylhydrazones of barbituric acid (AHBA) also attracted some attention , but have not been further investigated. Moreover, the coordination chemistry of AHBA ligands is almost unexplored , and deserves more attention in particular towards the preparation of water-soluble polymeric complexes.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Thus, taking in mind the above considerations, we focused this work on the following aims: <ce:italic>i</ce:italic>) to prepare a new water-soluble AHBA, 2-hydroxy-5-nitro-3-(2-(2,4,6-trioxotetrahydro-pyrimidin-5(2H)-ylidene)hydrazinyl)benzene sulfonic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>); (<ce:italic>ii</ce:italic>) to synthesize a derived new water‐soluble heterometallic copper(II)-sodium complex and shed light on its structural details and coordination modes in the solid state.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thus, taking in mind the above considerations, we focused this work on the following aims: i) to prepare a new water-soluble AHBA, 2-hydroxy-5-nitro-3-(2-(2,4,6-trioxotetrahydro-pyrimidin-5(2H)-ylidene)hydrazinyl)benzene sulfonic acid (H3L, 1) ( ); (ii) to synthesize a derived new water-soluble heterometallic copper(II)-sodium complex and shed light on its structural details and coordination modes in the solid state.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The new AHBA ligand, 2-hydroxy-5-nitro-3-(2-(2,4,6-trioxotetrahydropyrimidin-5(2H)-ylidene) hydrazinyl)benzene sulfonic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was synthesized via the Japp–Klingemann reaction  between the respective aromatic diazonium salt and barbituric acid in water-ethanol solution containing sodium hydroxide (see Supplementary Information for details). The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(OH) at 3487<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(NH) at 3399, 3043, 2834<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. The carbonyl [ν(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O) 1712 and 1655, ν(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O∙∙∙H) 1590<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>] and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N) (1560<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>) vibrations indicate that in the solid state <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stabilized in the H-bonded hydrazo form. This conclusion is supported by the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C{<ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H} NMR data, <ce:italic>e.g.</ce:italic> the <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H-NMR spectrum of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L shows a signal at <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> 14.25 which can be assigned to the proton of the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>NH<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>hydrazone moiety adjacent to the aryl unit () .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The new AHBA ligand, 2-hydroxy-5-nitro-3-(2-(2,4,6-trioxotetrahydropyrimidin-5(2H)-ylidene) hydrazinyl)benzene sulfonic acid (H3L, 1) was synthesized via the Japp-Klingemann reaction  between the respective aromatic diazonium salt and barbituric acid in water-ethanol solution containing sodium hydroxide (see Supplementary Information for details). The IR spectrum of 1 reveals ν(OH) at 3487cm-1 and ν(NH) at 3399, 3043, 2834cm-1. The carbonyl [ν(CO) 1712 and 1655, ν(CO∙∙∙H) 1590cm-1] and ν(CN) (1560cm-1) vibrations indicate that in the solid state 1 is stabilized in the H-bonded hydrazo form. This conclusion is supported by the 1H and 13C{1H} NMR data, e.g. the 1H-NMR spectrum of H2L shows a signal at δ 14.25 which can be assigned to the proton of the CNNH-hydrazone moiety adjacent to the aryl unit () .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The heterometallic copper(II)-sodium 1D coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, {[Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(η<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>-L)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (), was obtained with 48% yield by mixing (stirring for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min) of a water solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L, NaOH and copper(II) nitrate hydrate at room temperature. Green crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained after 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d. The IR spectrum of this complex displays <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O) at 1699 and 1647<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, values significantly shifted in relation to those of the free ligand. Moreover, a hypsochromic shift in the UV–vis spectra of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is observed in comparison to the UV–vis spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (478 and 457<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively, see Fig. S1), confirming the n<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>π* or ligand-to-metal electron transitions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The heterometallic copper(II)-sodium 1D coordination polymer 2, {[Cu(H2O)Na(H2O)(η9-L)]⋅2H2O}n (), was obtained with 48% yield by mixing (stirring for 5min) of a water solution of H3L, NaOH and copper(II) nitrate hydrate at room temperature. Green crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained after 2d. The IR spectrum of this complex displays ν(CO) at 1699 and 1647cm-1, values significantly shifted in relation to those of the free ligand. Moreover, a hypsochromic shift in the UV-vis spectra of 2 is observed in comparison to the UV-vis spectra of 1 (478 and 457nm, for 1 and 2, respectively, see Fig. S1), confirming the n→π* or ligand-to-metal electron transitions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is constructed from copper(II) and sodium ions linked by fully deprotonated AHBA (L<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>) ligands in an overall η<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>-chelating mode, forming 1D chains interconnected by crystallization water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of 2 is constructed from copper(II) and sodium ions linked by fully deprotonated AHBA (L3-) ligands in an overall η9-chelating mode, forming 1D chains interconnected by crystallization water molecules (  ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Each copper atom is ligated to the phenolate-, one of the keto- and one of the sulphonate-oxygens, as well as to one nitrogen from the hydrazone ligand; a water molecule completes the coordination sphere of the metal, which assumes a five-coordinated structure (<ce:italic>τ</ce:italic> parameter of 0.18 ). The apical site is taken by the O12 oxygen of the sulfonate group of an adjacent η<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>-L moiety with a Cu1–O12<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>
</ce:sup> bond distance of 2.336(3) Å (), considerably longer than the remaining metal-oxygen bonds (in the 1.912(3)–1.976(3) Å range). Owing to the chelating behavior of L<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, the Cu atoms in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> participate in planar penta- and hexa-membered metallacycles (Cu1–O1–C1–C6–N1 and Cu1–N1–N2–C8–C9–O4, respectively). Extra metallacycles can also be envisaged: involving only one sodium cation (S1-C2-C1-O1-Na1-O11), two sodium cations [Na1-O12<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>(or O11<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>)-S1<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>-O13<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>-Na1<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>iii</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>-O12<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>-S1<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>-O13<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>] and several others involving both metals, the smallest one built from Cu1-O1-Na1-O13<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>-S1<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>-O12<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>
</ce:sup> (see  and legend for symmetry codes). The sodium cation can be envisaged as in a highly distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment (<ce:italic>τ</ce:italic> parameter of 0.38 ), but also in a hexagonal geometry if one considers the short range contact interaction with the O11-sulfonate oxygen from a vicinal L<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>i.e.</ce:italic> Na1–O11<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
</ce:sup>, as affective bond (2.842(4) Å). The shortest metal-metal distances found in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are of 3.855(2) (Cu–Na) and 3.733(3) Å (Na–Na).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each copper atom is ligated to the phenolate-, one of the keto- and one of the sulphonate-oxygens, as well as to one nitrogen from the hydrazone ligand; a water molecule completes the coordination sphere of the metal, which assumes a five-coordinated structure (τ parameter of 0.18 ). The apical site is taken by the O12 oxygen of the sulfonate group of an adjacent η9-L moiety with a Cu1-O12 v  bond distance of 2.336(3) Å (), considerably longer than the remaining metal-oxygen bonds (in the 1.912(3)-1.976(3) Å range). Owing to the chelating behavior of L3-, the Cu atoms in 2 participate in planar penta- and hexa-membered metallacycles (Cu1-O1-C1-C6-N1 and Cu1-N1-N2-C8-C9-O4, respectively). Extra metallacycles can also be envisaged: involving only one sodium cation (S1-C2-C1-O1-Na1-O11), two sodium cations [Na1-O12 i (or O11 i )-S1 i -O13 i -Na1 iii -O12 v -S1 v -O13 v ] and several others involving both metals, the smallest one built from Cu1-O1-Na1-O13 v -S1 v -O12 v  (see  and legend for symmetry codes). The sodium cation can be envisaged as in a highly distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment (τ parameter of 0.38 ), but also in a hexagonal geometry if one considers the short range contact interaction with the O11-sulfonate oxygen from a vicinal L3-, i.e. Na1-O11 i , as affective bond (2.842(4) Å). The shortest metal-metal distances found in 2 are of 3.855(2) (Cu-Na) and 3.733(3) Å (Na-Na).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The bonding parameters involving the copper cation (see ESI) are comparable to those of other Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>-AHAMC complexes , also suggesting overall electron density delocalization. Indeed, both the 5- and the 6-membered copper metallacycles are involved in intrachain interactions with the pyrimidine-dione and the phenyl rings, respectively (<ce:italic>centroid</ce:italic>∙∙∙<ce:italic>centroid</ce:italic> distances of 3.721(3) and 3.570(3) Å, in that order). However, the strongest interaction is achieved between the two organic rings of L<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>centroid</ce:italic>∙∙∙<ce:italic>centroid</ce:italic> distance of 3.452<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The bonding parameters involving the copper cation (see ESI) are comparable to those of other CuII-AHAMC complexes , also suggesting overall electron density delocalization. Indeed, both the 5- and the 6-membered copper metallacycles are involved in intrachain interactions with the pyrimidine-dione and the phenyl rings, respectively (centroid∙∙∙centroid distances of 3.721(3) and 3.570(3) Å, in that order). However, the strongest interaction is achieved between the two organic rings of L3- (centroid∙∙∙centroid distance of 3.452Å).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Several medium strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds were found in the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Many of them involve both the coordinated and crystallization water molecules simultaneously as donors and acceptors, therefore linking the 1D metal-organic chains () and expanding the structure to the second and third dimensions (Table S2).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Several medium strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds were found in the structure of 2. Many of them involve both the coordinated and crystallization water molecules simultaneously as donors and acceptors, therefore linking the 1D metal-organic chains () and expanding the structure to the second and third dimensions (Table S2).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, we have synthesized and fully characterized a novel water-soluble heterometallic copper(II)-sodium 1D coordination polymer, {[Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(η<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>-L)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, which is constructed by the reaction, in water, of copper(II) nitrate hydrate, sodium hydroxide and the new multi-functionalized AHBA <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, along with other functional groups, the water molecules play an essential role in stabilization of the structure as hydrogen bond donors and acceptors. The application of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in catalysis and the preparation of other metal complexes with ligand <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are currently under investigation in our laboratory.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have synthesized and fully characterized a novel water-soluble heterometallic copper(II)-sodium 1D coordination polymer, {[Cu(H2O)Na(H2O)(η9-L)]⋅2H2O}n 2, which is constructed by the reaction, in water, of copper(II) nitrate hydrate, sodium hydroxide and the new multi-functionalized AHBA 1. In 2, along with other functional groups, the water molecules play an essential role in stabilization of the structure as hydrogen bond donors and acceptors. The application of complex 2 in catalysis and the preparation of other metal complexes with ligand 1 are currently under investigation in our laboratory.

This data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>. Supplementary data to this article can be found online at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2012.06.008" xlink:type="simple">http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2012.06.008</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

    Supplementary materials 1.        Supplementary materials 2.     

Supplementary material

CCDC no. 867440 for {[Cu(H2O)Na(H2O)(η9-L)]⋅2H2O}n contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. This data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2012.06.008.

cln_elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The heterometallic copper(II)-sodium 1D coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, {[Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(η<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>-L)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (), was obtained with 48% yield by mixing (stirring for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min) of a water solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L, NaOH and copper(II) nitrate hydrate at room temperature. Green crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained after 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d. The IR spectrum of this complex displays <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O) at 1699 and 1647<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, values significantly shifted in relation to those of the free ligand. Moreover, a hypsochromic shift in the UV–vis spectra of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is observed in comparison to the UV–vis spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (478 and 457<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively, see Fig. S1), confirming the n<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>π* or ligand-to-metal electron transitions.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: The heterometallic copper(II)-sodium 1D coordination polymer 2, {[Cu(H2O)Na(H2O)(η9-L)]⋅2H2O}n (), was obtained with 48% yield by mixing (stirring for 5min) of a water solution of H3L, NaOH and copper(II) nitrate hydrate at room temperature. Green crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained after 2d. The IR spectrum of this complex displays ν(CO) at 1699 and 1647cm-1, values significantly shifted in relation to those of the free ligand. Moreover, a hypsochromic shift in the UV-vis spectra of 2 is observed in comparison to the UV-vis spectra of 1 (478 and 457nm, for 1 and 2, respectively, see Fig. S1), confirming the n→π* or ligand-to-metal electron transitions.
